title: 115_s1333
content: The "Tribal HUD-VASH Act of 2017" establishes a rental assistance program for homeless or at-risk Indian veterans living on or near a reservation. Eligible Indian veterans must be homeless or at risk of homelessness to qualify for the program. The "Tribal HUD-VASH Act of 2017" provides rental assistance for homeless or at-risk Indian veterans living on or near a reservation. Eligible veterans must be homeless or at risk of homelessness to qualify for the program. The term 'eligible recipient' refers to a recipient eligible for a grant under the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996. The terms 'Indian' and 'Indian area' are defined in the same Act. The term 'Indian veteran' refers to an Indian who is a veteran. The term 'Program' means the Tribal HUD-VASH program. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The Secretary must allocate at least 5 percent of the funds for rental assistance in the Program. The Tribal HUD-VASH program provides rental assistance and supported housing for eligible Indian veterans in collaboration with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Program is modeled after existing rental assistance and supported housing programs authorized by applicable appropriations Acts. The Tribal HUD-VASH program, in collaboration with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, allows for necessary modifications to facilitate the use of the Program by eligible recipients after consultation with Indian tribes and other appropriate tribal organizations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may make modifications to facilitate the use of the program by eligible recipients to serve eligible Indian veterans, after consulting with Indian tribes and tribal organizations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide rental assistance and administrative grants to eligible recipients based on need, administrative capacity, and other funding criteria established in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will administer grants under the Program in accordance with the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act of 1996. Recipients must submit reports on rental assistance utilization and provide specified information to the Secretary. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, will consult with grant recipients and tribal organizations to design the Program for effective delivery of rental assistance and supportive services to eligible Indian veterans. The Indian Health Service Director will assist the Secretary and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in implementing the Program for Indian veterans. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify requirements of laws and regulations for the Program. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for the effective delivery of rental assistance under the Program to eligible Indian veterans, except for provisions related to labor standards or the environment. The Secretary may set aside funds for renewal grants to eligible recipients who previously received a grant under the Program, specifying criteria for eligibility. The Secretary may set aside funds for renewal grants to eligible recipients who previously received a grant under the Program, specifying criteria for eligibility. Eligible recipients must report on how previous grant amounts were used. The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Director of the Indian Health Service, must conduct a review every 5 years. The Secretary must review the implementation of the Program and submit a report on any limiting factors to designated authorities. The Secretary must review the implementation of the Program and report to designated Senate committees. The Subcommittee on Indian, Insular and Alaska Native Affairs of the House of Representatives, along with other committees, will be involved in reviewing the implementation of the Program. The Secretary's initial report will include a description of regulations governing the use of current assisted stock and the number of grant recipients under the Program. The Secretary's initial report will include a description of regulations governing the use of current assisted stock and proposed alternative legislation or regulations developed in consultation with grant recipients under the Program. The Senate passed the legislation on May 23, 2018, as attested by Secretary JULIE E. ADAMS.
